After spending 162 hours in Path of Exile, I can confidently say it is the best action RPG I have ever played. The depth and complexity of the game are remarkable, and the amount of endgame content is simply staggering. Just when I think I have seen everything, I discover something new, whether it is a fresh mechanic, a clever build idea, or another layer of progression that changes how I approach the game. The Atlas tree stands out as one of the most impressive systems in any ARPG. It gives you complete control over your endgame experience, allowing you to tailor your mapping and content to your preferred playstyle. Whether you enjoy delving into the mines, hunting bosses, or farming for loot, the Atlas tree makes every choice feel meaningful and rewarding. The gameplay itself is incredibly visceral and satisfying. Every build feels unique, every skill feels powerful once you invest in it, and combat always demands your attention. There is a real sense of weight and impact in every fight, and the satisfaction of seeing your build come together never gets old. Even after more than 160 hours, I still feel like I have only scratched the surface of what the game offers. Path of Exile rewards experimentation, planning, and a willingness to learn. It is a game that challenges you but also gives back tenfold in depth and enjoyment. If you are a fan of action RPGs and have not tried Path of Exile yet, you are missing out on something special. Be warned though, once you start, it is easy to lose track of time. This game pulls you in and does not let go.

Over the last decade I tried a few times to get into this game, since in general I like isometric ARPGs. But back in 2015, 2018 and 2022 I played for many hours but couldn't get past the campaign. 
Then in december 2024 I opted into the early access of Path of Exile 2 and the game was (and still is) a great experience. So around christmas '24 I tried PoE again, but again I couldn't get past the campaign. The lack of the quality of life improvements and gameplay feel of PoE2 made it unenjoyable for me.

Near the end of Mercenary league I made the plan to "force" myself into the endgame of PoE at least once. So I played Righteous Fire Chieftain, had good fun in the campaign and could explore some of the endgame. I enjoyed the time so I opted into the new league - Keepers of the Flame - and followed a build guide for Siege Ballista Hierophant. I had a blast during the campaign (even though it is very long) and now I'm in red maps, explored the Atlas 85/115 and I am thoroughly hooked. Overcoming the lack of gameplay polish that is present in PoE2 I acknowledge that PoE bit by bit is getting more QoL improvements.

I think now it finally clicked with me. I found my jam with PoE and PoE2, no need for any other game anymore. Every two months I get to experience something new and improved in both games.

If you play Solo Self Found (the much more fun gamemode if you like off-meta theorycrafting), you will hit wall after wall where you need to grind content to piece together incremental upgrades for your character on your own.

I enjoy the gameplay and diverse character customization systems. I dislike the egregiously tedious itemization and crafting system. 

Imagine a world where 80% of loot drops are trash. 15% are crafting fodder, which will have you running back and forth to vendors. And the remaining %5 are items of interest. That's POE. 

I feel like the developers of this game forgot they were making an ARPG and instead made a nut collecting simulator for squirrels, except the nuts are various crafting materials and the squirrels are US. 

Also, all currency is interchangeable via the currency exchange. Therefore, loot variety is an illusion. I would much prefer "gold" or some singular progression currency be dropped instead of hundreds of different objects that have to be collected, sorted, managed in your inventory, etc. 

In the end game, you can even have NPC's play the game for you by running maps in Path of Exile Ville. I felt excited when those NPC bros reported back with loot. "A Chaos Orb!" I exclaimed. That's when I realized how bad the grindyness of this game is. What a relief it was that an NPC was able to do the crafting materials chores for me! 

Also, build variety and freedom is... kind of a myth? I seems like the balance of the game corrals you into narrower sets of choices than the immense passive skill tree would have you believe. Many builds won't work at all. Many skills are garbage. In the earlier parts of the game, you can get away with a lot more. However, when the game gets difficult at the end, you'll find yourself squeezing out every inefficiency from your build, and that will lead you to the realization that the vast majority of builds are doomed to not scale to the end game.  

I love ARPG's. I think POE has advanced the genre, but it's not the pinnacle of the category. I think there was a lot of genius behind this game, but they got lost along the way. We ARPG players want to develop our characters, explore cool places, collect cool gear, and kick ass. We don't want to play Path of Exile Ville; we don't want to play inventory manager 900.

A Masterclass in ARPG Design and Absolutely Free!

Path of Exile is a challenging, deep, and rewarding action RPG that is free to play. It has a steep learning curve, but the payoff is a rich, complex game world that can absorb a significant amount of your time. This game is known for its extensive customization options, including a vast passive skill tree and a flexible skill gem system. It features a dark and gritty atmosphere that complements its challenging gameplay. The developers regularly release large, free expansions, keeping the game fresh with new mechanics and content. While it is free to play, the game is supported by the sale of cosmetic items and optional quality-of-life features, with no pay-to-win elements.

[h3][b]Path of Exile: A Beautiful, Chaotic, Loot-Splattered Nightmare (And I Love It)[/b][/h3]
Path of Exile is the only game where I can confidently say I‚Äôve spent [b]more time researching than actually playing[/b], and still feel like I‚Äôm doing everything wrong. It‚Äôs an action RPG that throws you into a continent of murder, misery, and morally questionable NPCs, and says:
 [b]‚ÄúGood luck, exile. Try not to explode.‚Äù[/b]
[h2][b]The Tutorial Is a Lie[/b][/h2]
The game starts off beautifully: you wake up on a beach, beat up some zombies, walk into town, and think, ‚ÄúHey, this isn‚Äôt so bad.‚Äù
 Then you open the [b]Skill Tree[/b], which looks less like a progression system and more like the [b]Hadron Collider sneezed onto graph paper[/b].
You want to build a fire mage? Cool, here‚Äôs 400 nodes. One of them is good. The others give you things like +10 to Intelligence, +12% to Fire Damage, or the ability to accidentally brick your entire build without realizing it for 30 hours.
And yet‚Ä¶ I keep returning.
[h2][b]Loot: A Never-Ending Rain of Questionable Decisions[/b][/h2]
No other game produces quite the same emotional rollercoaster as seeing 500 items explode out of a monster like it just swallowed a garage sale. Ninety-nine percent of the loot is garbage, but you pick it up anyway because:
[list]
	[*]It [i]might[/i] be good.
	[*]It [i]might[/i] sell for currency.
	[*]It [i]might[/i] be vendor trash but you‚Äôre too emotionally weak to leave it behind.
[/list]
Every time I open my stash, it looks like a dragon hoarded random garbage instead of gold.
I don‚Äôt even know how half of it works. ‚ÄúFractured Influenced Synthesized Eldritch Rare‚Äù sounds like a medical condition, not an item type.
[h2][b]Monsters: Highly Trained Assassins[/b][/h2]
PoE monsters, especially in endgame, are like Olympic athletes of violence. They don‚Äôt approach you slowly. They don‚Äôt threaten you dramatically. They just appear, blink twice, and your character folds like a lawn chair in a hurricane.
I‚Äôve been one-shot so many times I‚Äôm convinced the mobs are unionized and receive bonuses for creative death animations.
[b]Off-screen goat leaps[/b] are the true final boss of this game.
 Sirus? Shaper? Elder? Nah.
 A goat on a cliff somewhere in Act 2 is the real menace.
[h2][b]Mapping: The Endgame Where You Pretend You Know What You‚Äôre Doing[/b][/h2]
Once you finish the campaign (or skip it because you‚Äôve already done it more times than you've showered this week), you arrive at the [b]Atlas[/b], where PoE hands you 500 combinations of mechanics and says, ‚ÄúPick your poison.‚Äù
You can:
[list]
	[*]Farm currency like a responsible adult
	[*]Run Heists with NPCs who all sound like they belong in a D&D tavern
	[*]Go Delving, aka ‚Äútorchlit cave sprinting while everything screams at you‚Äù
	[*]Fight bosses who politely inform you that ‚Äúresistance is futile, exile‚Äù
	[*]Or spend 40 minutes rolling a map just to die in the first pack anyway
[/list]
It‚Äôs like a theme park run entirely by caffeinated mad scientists.
[h2][b]NPCs: Questionable People with Great Voice Acting[/b][/h2]
Every NPC looks like they haven't slept since Act 1, and they all deliver their lines as if they‚Äôre auditioning for a grimdark Shakespeare production. Meanwhile, I'm standing there with a helmet that looks like a cosmic basketball court on fire, nodding like I understand lore I definitely do not.
[h2][b]The Real Endgame: Your Hideout[/b][/h2]
Some players decorate their hideout with beauty, elegance, symmetry.
Mine looks like a garage where several wizards died fighting over interior design choices.
[h2][b]In Conclusion: Chaos, Pain, Joy[/b][/h2]
Path of Exile is a game where:
[list]
	[*][b]Your build will fail.[/b]
	[*][b]Your first 30 hours will be confusion.[/b]
	[*][b]Your next 300 hours will be slightly more informed confusion.[/b]
	[*][b]You will die. Constantly.[/b]
	[*][b]And you will keep coming back.[/b]
[/list]
PoE isn‚Äôt a game.
 It‚Äôs a lifestyle.
 A hobby.
 A second job you pay for in brain cells.
 A place where math, violence, and fashion collide in perfect harmony.

I love Path of Exile. I‚Äôve played it for years. The game itself is incredible.

But the support system?
It is genuinely one of the worst I have ever seen in a live-service game.

I contacted support about a trade interface issue, something simple that should have taken basic guidance. Instead, I got a chain of replies so dismissive and low-effort that it honestly shocked me.

Every message was either:

‚Ä¢ A copy-paste template
‚Ä¢ A link to years-old, irrelevant documentation
‚Ä¢ Or a curt response telling me they ‚Äúcan‚Äôt help‚Äù

And when support did write something original, the emails were full of rushed phrasing, unclear sentences, and mistakes that made it obvious they were not trained, supported, or equipped to help anyone. It felt like the entire department is severely underfunded and understaffed, like GGG is cutting costs as hard as possible in the one area players rely on when something actually goes wrong.

They even admitted they are flooded with similar reports but ‚Äútoo busy‚Äù to look into any of them. No escalation, no clarity, no willingness to help. Just ‚Äúwe can‚Äôt do anything‚Äù and ‚Äústop asking.‚Äù

This is not a support system. It is a wall.

The tone was dismissive, the communication unprofessional, and the structure seems designed to push players away rather than assist them. I have never seen a company deliver such an amazing game while offering support this weak and poorly maintained.

Path of Exile is brilliant.
Path of Exile‚Äôs support is a disaster.
If something goes wrong, expect to be handed outdated links, template replies, and a clear message that you are on your own.

Until GGG invests in a real support team that is trained, staffed, and empowered to actually help, this will remain a major stain on an otherwise incredible game.

Path of Exile 1 is a great game trapped inside a technical framework that feels like it was built without long-term thinking or real engineering discipline.

The developers keep stacking new systems, new calculations, and massive on-screen load without ever proving they can handle the fundamentals. If you can‚Äôt design scalable systems or maintain server stability, you shouldn‚Äôt keep piling more complexity on top ‚Äî it only exposes the weaknesses even more.

The result is the same: lag spikes, server stutter, desync, and performance issues that follow you no matter your hardware. Once high pack size, multiple league mechanics, or heavy monster density appear, the game stops feeling like an ARPG and starts feeling like a stress test for bad infrastructure.

What‚Äôs most painful is that it feels like the team doesn‚Äôt understand their own engine anymore. The systems don‚Äôt work together, the servers can‚Äôt keep up, and the technical debt is so obvious that players can predict exactly when the game will break. That kind of failure doesn‚Äôt come from lack of resources ‚Äî it comes from lack of direction.

And to make it worse, there‚Äôs the long-standing issue that regular players constantly struggle with lag while certain streamers seem to enjoy perfectly smooth performance. Whether it‚Äôs priority servers, special queue placement, or some form of backend favoritism, the outcome is the same: one group gets flawless gameplay while everyone else suffers. That disparity alone speaks volumes about where the attention goes ‚Äî and where it doesn‚Äôt.

If the people responsible for these core systems truly believe this level of performance is acceptable, then that alone says everything. Sometimes the hardest truth is this: when a team refuses to improve the basics, it‚Äôs a sign they‚Äôve reached the limits of what they can do.

The game is brilliant at its core, but the technical foundation is so poorly handled it overshadows everything good about it.

Actually POE is in many ways worse than Diablo III.

1) POE has a microtransaction shop with items easily costing dozens of bucks each - D3 removed the Auction House.
2) D3 has much lower system recommendations despite having about the same amount of data.
3) POE loading times are immense - even to the tiny first village.
4) In POE every item is socketable - it is not rare and has no value.
5) POE melee attack animations look awkward and something you see in a cheap indie game.

POE has a lot of really boneheaded technical design blunders that anyone with ANY competence would have ironed out in the early alpha-testing phase a decade ago.

1. If you are recording the game with OBS and you change the game resolution, the game will crash. Shortly before crashing it will show an message box mentioning "swapchains", recording with OBS and suggesting the use of the Window capture mode. Reality check: the game is not capturable in Window Capture (read: enjoy the black screen) with OBS. Reality Check 2: no other game has issues with OBS recording, not even the cheapest indie games. Clearly the developers do not know the basics.

2. Changing the sound channel amount requires a restart.

3. Changing the Direct X mode requires a restart. What is this - Windows 95 era software design of restarting after every minor change. Also, most other games let you select the DX mode BEFORE you start the 50-gigabyte software.

4. DX 12 mode (default) takes up about 4.0 gigabytes in the menu. What is this - designed by Ubisoft?

5. DX 11 mode takes about 2.0 gigabytes of RAM in the menu. WTF does the difference of a DX version double the memory requirements and why is the more demanding one default and why cannot you select it before booting the software.

6. POE utilizes the same anti-pattern design as the criticized The Crew games with the centralized server for no reason. That means when the service is terminated, your purchases are rendered worthless. Everything - including the menus - has the loading swirly as if I was accessing a website in 1996 with a dial-up connection.

Oh that centralized server issue became apparent instantly. "Connection disconnected unexpedtedly."

7. Why is the game still stuck with the mouse-click-based controls when you have a keyboard with directional inputs. Why make a 50 gig game with such a mobile game control scheme. It is not 1997 anymore - it is almost 30 years already. A single-unit  control scheme should not be the same as an RTS game.

8. The massive skill tree makes locating the skills you want as difficult as possible. Sure you can use the "search", though all it does is highlight the matching skill names a little. It is barely noticeably. Why not instead do the basic CTRL+F function even a Windows f-ing Notepad can do and take you to the first entry. It does not even tell you how many matches you got. It is completely useless.

9. The classes are poorly explained. At the beginning you are given a choice between half a dozen obscure class titles such as 'duelist', 'ranger' and 'marauder.' What you are not told is that the class choice affects what ultimate second classes you can pick because apparently they are tied to those specific classes. All builds are based on the unexplained second-tier classes and you are not told what class you should pick to access a specific Tier 2 one. Why hide the essential information. This is such a lose-lose design that helps no one.

10. The game runs like garbage especially in villages and where other people are located at. It quickly becomes a low-performance diorama. If you just want to play the game and not get frame-rate-nerfed by the mere vicinity of other players, you are going to feel the lack of a genuine single-player mode.

The real reason for why the single player mode is not there is because they cannot sell you ultimately worthless microtransactions if you are not connected to their server. That is right: 1. the game calls it a "microtransaction shop" and 2. you are not connecting to the game - you are connecting to the store front. The gameplay areas are simply a sideshow for the worthless bit dealing to take away lonely players cope money.

11. The game lacks direction. Much like in MOBAs such as League of Legends, you are expected to simply know what you must do and the game will give you nothing while expecting you to already know everything or to look up guides to make sense out of the vapid nothingness the game is. There really is no plot - the enemies are there mostly to be target practice for the skills and to drop something (useless).

12. The obsession with hordes from Diablo 3 is here. Even in the beginning are you are really met with enemy groups smaller that four. In the end game footage people are blasting entire screens full of mobs with one move. When you make the mass monster nuking into a recurring occurrence, it gets old fast and stops being fun. It is as if the game is telling you: "look at how much you murdered, now like this game and go to the microtransaction shop and like every item there by buying everything there - IN TRIPLICATES!!"

I get the feeling the developers are not the best. Especially not at game design. They managed to rip off also the bad parts from Diablo III. Like they say:  some people cannot grasp and create their own things, so all they end up doing is mindlessly stealing things in hopes of replicating the success.

POE feels so bad I would rather try Diablo III instead and that game is a snorefest.

This game might appeal to you if you have lots and lots of money and an itty-bitty tiny ego.
